notes.div: CYAF 150 is 'Letter Grade only'.

div.span: Ecological Systems Theory is introduced as a foundation to understand the complex college environment and how basic life skills can be used to achieve success in college. How to apply systems theory to the following challenges: study skills and time management; awareness of diversity of thought and action; leadership; community service and social responsibility; money management; coping with stress; developing healthy social relationships; and career exploration.

description.div: Developmental life cycle approach to the study of the individual from conception to death. Each stage of life studied from the perspective of how individual development is fostered within the family system.

course.title: Honors: Human Development and the Family

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation.

description.div: For course description, see FACS 160.

course.title: Introduction to Early Child Care and Education

description.div: Introduction to early care and education and applied child development. Different philosophical and educational approaches to working with young children with a range of abilities in a variety of settings.

prerequisite.div: Sophomore standing.

notes.div: Not open to students with credit in FINA 260 or equivalent.

description.div: Individual and family financial planning. Emphasis on financial planning for families in the early life cycle. Application of credit, insurance, savings, investments, taxes, and estate planning information to individual and family needs.

prerequisite.div: FACS 160 or 160H, or equivalent; parallel FACS 270L.

description.div: Growth and behavior related to the preschool years, ages two through five.

prerequisite.div: FACS 160 or 160H, or equivalent. Parallel FACS 270.

notes.div: CYAF 270L is 'Pass/No Pass only'.

description.div: Observation of and participation in the care and guidance of preschool children.

prerequisite.div: FACS 160 or 160H, or equivalent; parallel FACS 271L.

description.div: Human growth and behavior from conception to three years of age from a holistic and ecological perspective including application of knowledge to the care and education of infants and toddlers.

prerequisite.div: FACS 160 or 160H, or equivalent. Parallel FACS 271.

notes.div: CYAF 271L is 'Pass/No Pass only'.

description.div: Human growth and behavior from conception to three years of age.

Introduction to research and theory on family relationships and to careers working with children and families. Family systems and how they are affected by healthy and unhealthy processes. How ethnicity, gender and social class influences family living.

The complexities of dating and diverse couple relationships from both developmental and family system perspectives. Research on the formation, dissolution, and maintenance of relationships. Promotion of healthy communication and interactional patterns. The influence of family of origin dynamics, culture, gender, and life cycle transitions.

prerequisite.div: Admission to the FCS education program;

notes.div:
Must take CYAF 297J (1 cr) with CYAF 451/851.
An accompanying seminar is included where the role of the professional is discussed. CYAF 297J is 'Letter grade only'.

div.p: Guided observations and/or clinical experiences in schools and/or agencies offering programs for children, youth, and families.

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation; College of Education and Human Sciences honor program student; and a major in one of the Human Sciences areas Grade only.

description.div: Human growth and behavior from conception to three years of age.

prerequisite.div: FACS 222.

description.div: Critical analyses and intervention strategies of family finance issues across the life span.

The determinants of economic well-being of individuals and families over time. The consequences of family economic well-being for family functioning and outcomes. Family economics theories and concepts. How families develop, acquire, maintain, and conserve scarce resources to attain desired standards of living.

course.title: Methods of Working with Infants in Programs and Communities

prerequisite.div: CYAF 271 and 271L, with a grades of 'Pass' or 'C' or better.

description.div: Program models used in programs serving infants and toddlers. Center-based and home-based models. Curricula, training programs, and methods of assessment used in infant-toddler programs. Current state efforts to define standards and outcomes for infants and toddlers.

prerequisite.div: FACS 160 or 160H or equivalent.

description.div: Theoretical interrelationships of the physiological, psychological, and sociological and cognitive aspects of development during the years after early childhood through adolescence.

course.title: Curriculum Planning in Early Childhood Education

prerequisite.div: FACS 160 or 160H, and 270; parallel FACS 374L.

description.div: Best practices in early childhood education and the teacher's role in facilitating childhood learning through planning, implementing, sequencing, documenting, and evaluating early childhood instruction.

course.title: Curriculum Planning in Early Childhood Education Laboratory

prerequisite.div: FACS 160 or 160H, and 270; parallel FACS 374.

description.div: Planning, implementing, and evaluating developmentally appropriate activities for young children in a supervised early childhood laboratory setting.

course.title: Working with Families in Communities and Schools

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs in major.

description.div: The theoretical foundations for working with families in the community and school. Professional interaction skills needed to establish sound working relationships with families. Ethical guidelines for professional interactions with families to facilitate appropriate application of principles to the diversity of professions working with families.

prerequisite.div: FACS 160 or 160H, 222, 280, and with an overall minimum grade average of 2.5 for these three courses.

notes.div: Includes a pre-practicum fieldwork experience.

description.div: Theories and skills for assessment, intervention, and referral.

prerequisite.div: Sophomore standing.

description.div: Introduction to principles of parenting within multidimensional contexts, including developmental, structural, and cultural perspectives. Biopsychosocial aspects of parenting in relationship to family life cycles. Evidence-based practices for personal and programmatic application.

prerequisite.div: CYAF 374 and 374L.

description.div: Research base and historical antecedents of current theories of literacy development in young children. The specific connection between those theories and construction and successful implementation of developmentally appropriate, relationship rich-literacy methods, strategies, materials, and environments for children from birth to age five. Assessment tools of teacher effectiveness and early literacy acquisition, formal and informal techniques.

course.title: World of Wonder: Math, Science and Nature Integrated Methods Birth to Age 5

prerequisite.div: CYAF 170 or equivalent.

description.div: The development and learning of children from birth to age five in the domains of math, science, and nature. The developmentally appropriate methods for supporting children's development in these domains.

course.title: Applied Methods of Social Emotional Development and Guidance

prerequisite.div: CYAF 170, 270, and 270L; parallel CYAF 385L.

notes.div: CYAF 385 is for people interested in working with children in schools, child care programs, and in social service agencies.

description.div: An overview of the components of social competence and what influences its development. Common social difficulties experienced by children and enhancing children's social competence.

course.title: Applied Methods of Social Emotional Development and Guidance

prerequisite.div: CYAF 170, 270, and 270L; parallel CYAF 385.

notes.div: CYAF 385L is for students to improve their ability to interact effectively with young children. CYAF 385L provides a bridge between theory and practice, complementing CYAF 385. CYAF 385L is 'Pass/No Pass only'.

description.div: Practice and demonstrate behaviors and skills related to sound child development theory and/or research and best practices under the guidance of early childhood professionals.

course.title: Independent Study in Child, Youth and Family Studies

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs CYAF or closely related areas; and permission.

notes.div: CYAF 396 requires a completed contract form before registering.

description.div: Individual problems and readings in current literature.

course.title: Honors: Independent Study in Child, Youth and Family Studies

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation; 12 hrs CYAF or closely related areas; and permission. CYAF 396H is 'Letter Grade Only'.

div.em: CYAF 396H requires a completed contract form before registering.

description.div: Individual problems and readings in current literature under the direction of a faculty member in the department.

prerequisite.div: Admission to the FCS education program;

notes.div: Must take CYAF 397J (1 cr) with CYAF 452/852. CYAF 397J is 'Letter grade only'.

description.div: Guided observations and/or clinical experiences in schools and/or agencies offering programs for children, youth, and families.

course.title: Student Teaching Seminar in Family and Consumer Sciences

prerequisite.div: Parallel CYAF 497J/897J.

description.div: Analysis of school programs with attention to: teacher certification in Family and Consumer Sciences; teacher and student rights and responsibilities; proper conduct of teachers; selected legal aspects of education; methods of communicating with parents and community members; current issues which impact education; and reflection and discussion of student teaching experiences. Reinforcement of learning theories, teaching principles, management, and best practices.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing.

notes.div: Not open to family and consumer sciences education majors in the certification track.

description.div: Planning and implementing developmentally appropriate educational experiences for a variety of audiences in non-formal settings.

Introduction to addictions from a family systems perspective: theories; behavioral patterns; physiological, psychological and social impacts on individuals and the family; and implications for interventions and treatment.

course.title: Working with GLBT Youth in Professional Contexts

description.div: To introduce contextual considerations and research-informed guidelines for working with Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual, and Transgender youth in professional settings such as educational, mental health, medical, and community outreach. The systemic context of GLBT youth, including developmental transitions, unique stressors, peer relationships, and familial environments, will be explored. Ways to help GLBT youth thrive will be emphasized.

course.title: Learning and Teaching Principles and Practices in Family and Consumer Sciences

prerequisite.div: Admission to the Teacher Education Program; completion of 80% of subject area coursework with a 2.5 GPA or better; parallel CYAF 297J (1 cr) or CYAF 897 (1cr).

description.div: Theoretical issues in the area of teaching and learning as applied in Family and Consumer Sciences. Development of middle and secondary education curriculum in Family and Consumer Sciences using student-centered, interactive methods of instruction.

course.title: Curriculum Principles and Practices in Family and Consumer Sciences

prerequisite.div: Admission to the Teacher Education Program; completion of 80% of subject area course work with a 2.5 GPA or better; CYAF 451/851; parallel CYAF 397J (1 cr) or CYAF 897J (1 cr).

description.div: Practical issues in the area of teaching and learning as applied to Family and Consumer Sciences. Develop teaching and/or learning plans for teaching Family and Consumer Sciences. Analyze classroom management practices and develop plans for assessment.

course.title: Family Stress and Crisis, Coping and Recovery

prerequisite.div: Junior standing.

notes.div: CYAF 458 is 'Letter grade only'.

description.div: Normative and non-normative family stressors (e.g. violence, economic conditions, war and political conflict, natural disasters) and how they affect family functioning. Family stress theories are used to understand crisis events and how families can cope and recover.
Human development from young adulthood to old age. Interaction of, and changes in, physical, psychological, and social-relational development.

course.title: Program Design, Implementation and Evaluation in Family and Human Sciences

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs family and consumer sciences or related social sciences.

notes.div: Participation in a community-based project involving the practical application of program design and evaluation methods is required.

description.div: Principles and methods of program design, implementation, and outcome evaluation of children and family programs.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing and 12 hrs in one of the departments in which the course is listed.

notes.div: Open to advanced students planning careers in the professions in which knowledge of human behavior and society is important (e.g., helping professions, medicine, law, ministry, education, etc.).

description.div: Interdisciplinary approach to the study of human sexuality in terms of the psychological, social, cultural, anthropological, legal, historical, and physical characteristics of individual sexuality and sex in society.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs family and consumer science, or related social sciences including FACS 270 and 270L.

description.div: Selection, use, and interpretation of assessment instruments for understanding the developmental level of children from birth through age eight. Assessment of reasoning and thinking processes, concept formation, and social cognition.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs FACS, and/or related social sciences including FACS 270, 270L.

description.div: Nature and development of reasoning and thinking processes and concept formation in children. Contribution of Piaget and others in providing new insights. Implications of these for teachers, parents, and others working with young children.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs family and consumer sciences including FACS 270.

description.div: Administration of early childhood programs.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing.

description.div: Analysis of child and family policies, including what is family policy, how policy is made and implemented, how values and goals affect policy and future directions for child and family policies in America and in other countries.

Special topics related to child, youth, and family studies. Topics vary.
A. Early Childhood (1-3 cr, max 3) Lec.; D. Family Science (1-3 cr, max 3) Lec.; J. Family and Consumer Science Education (1-3 cr, max 3) Lec.; Y. Youth Development (1-3 cr, max 3) Lec.

course.title: Special Topics in Contemporary Family Issues

description.div: Current issues such as debt management, gender and family, low-income families, retirement planning, work and family, mothering, fathering, housing. Topics vary.

course.title: Special Topics in Family and Cultural Diversity

description.div: Current topics related to diverse populations, e.g., religion, sexual orientation, ethnicity. Topics vary.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs CYAF and/or related social sciences.

notes.div: CYAF 496/896 requires a contract and the contract is to be completed before registering for the course. Work in CYAF 496/896 is supervised and evaluated by a CYAF faculty member.

description.div: Individual projects in research, literature review, or creative production may or may not be an extension of course work.

prerequisite.div: CYAF 270 and 270L; CYAF 374 and 374L, with grades of 'C' or better. Inclusive Early Childhood: Birth to Age 3 (IECE) option students must also have taken SPED 362 with a grade of 'C' or better.

notes.div: Pass/No Pass only.

description.div: Integrating developmental theory into the planning, implementation, and evaluation of individual and group experiences for young children in child development laboratory.

course.title: Community Internships in Child, Youth and Family Studies

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; 12 hrs FACS or other social sciences.

description.div: Fieldwork in agencies serving children, youth, families and communities.

course.title: Student Teaching in an Infant/Toddler Program

prerequisite.div: CYAF 497A.

notes.div: Pass/No Pass Only.

description.div: Integrated developmental theories and research evidence into the planning, implementation, and evaluation of individual and group experiences for children in an infant and toddler program.

course.title: Student Teaching in Family and Consumer Sciences

prerequisite.div: Admission by application; completion of all required methods courses and practica with minimum grade of 'C+' (2.33) in each of these courses.

notes.div: CYAF 497J/897J requires one middle-level and one high school experience. CYAF 497J is 'Pass/No Pass only'.

description.div: Supervised teaching experience in schools.

prerequisite.div: CYAF 497A.

notes.div: Pass/No Pass Only.

description.div: Integrating developmental theories and research evidence into the planning, implementation, and evaluation of individual and group experiences for children in a classroom experience.

course.title: Child, Youth and Family Studies Research

description.div: Application of principles of research design and methods to a specific area of research.

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation.

notes.div: CYAF 499H requires a completed contract form before registering. CYAF 499H is 'Letter grade only'.

description.div: Honor thesis in Child, Youth and Family Studies.

prerequisite.div: ALEC 302.

description.div: Knowledge and theoretical basis for practicing supervisors in a changing workplace where supervisors have increasing responsibilities due to the flattening or organizational structures, solving supervisory challenges in organizing and planning, problem solving and decision making, performance appraisal and leading a diverse workforce.

course.title: UCARE, REU, Non-UCARE Research Experience in Child, Youth and Family Studies

div.em: CYAF 098/498 requires a completed contract form before registering.
CYAF 098 is zero credit hours and is 'Pass/No Pass only'.

description.div: Undergraduate Creative Research Experience (UCARE), Research Experience For Undergraduates (REU), and non-UCARE research and/or creative activity.
